Dear Ms. Clayton:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
June 1-4, 8-11 and 16, 2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also
violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, explain why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(b) Verification of education.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member’s performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
(2)(b) Six out of nine employee records reviewed were newly hired. In one out of six
newly hired employee records reviewed, the record did not include verification of
education.
(3)(a) Eight out of nine employee records reviewed required a written performance
evaluation within a probationary period or an annual written evaluation. In one out of
eight employee records reviewed, the probationary performance evaluation was
completed more than six months after the staff member assumed her current
responsibility. The employee was hired on October 28, 2019 and the probationary
performance evaluation was completed on June 4, 2020.
R 400.12309 Records check.
(3) An agency shall initiate a criminal history check of a resident
minor within 30 days after turning 18 years of age.
In one out of eight certification records reviewed, there was no documentation that
the agency initiated a criminal background check of a resident minor within 30 days
after she turned eighteen years of age. The minor resident turned eighteen years old
on August 24, 2019 and the criminal history check request was sent to DCWL on
June 1, 2020.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
4

In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the yearly medical exam was
not completed timely. The yearly medical exam was due by October 14, 2019 and it
was completed on March 10, 2020.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing
agency to another child placing agency, a modified service plan
must be completed within 30 calendar days of the change in
agency responsibility if no other plan is done within 30 days.
The plan shall address why the agency responsibility changed
and whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
(2)(b) In three out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, an updated service plan
(USP) was not completed at least once every 90 calendar days.
 For one foster child’s record, the USP was due on September 1, 2019 and it
was completed on September 2, 2019.
 For one foster child’s record, the USP was due on January 12, 2020 and it
was completed on January 15, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, the USP was due on October 20, 2019 and it
was completed on October 22, 2019.
(3) In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, in which a modified service
plan was required, the modified service plan was not completed within 30 days of the
agency receiving case responsibility. The agency received case responsibility on
December 2, 2019 and the modified service plan was not completed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED for (2)(b) —2018 Renewal Inspection, CAP
approved July 5, 2018.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED for (2)(b) —2019 Interim Inspection, CAP
approved September 19, 2019.
R 400.12604 Orientation and application.
(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for prospective
applicants for adoption before an adoptive application is
provided. The orientation shall include a review of all of the
following:
(a) Program statement, policies, and procedures.
(b) Needs and characteristics of children available for adoption.
(c) Services and resources available.
5

(d) Fees and charges.
(e) Legal process.
(f) Training requirements.
(g) Post adoption service availability.
In one out of six adoption family records reviewed, the agency did not provide an
orientation to the prospective adoptive parent before an adoptive application was
provided. The adoption application was signed on March 24, 2019 and the adoption
orientation was completed on March 25, 2019.

and recommendation upon its completion.

MCL 722.112a 722.112a Child caring institution, foster family home, foster

and family child care home; individual certified in first aid
and cardiopulmonary resuscitation; applicability of MCL
722.125.
Sec. 2a. (1) A child caring institution, foster family home, foster

prescribed in the appropriate administrative rules, who have
current certification in first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation

MCL 722.120 Confidentiality.
A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care and
shall report to the department, when requested, the facts
the department requires with reference to the children upon
forms furnished by the department. Except as otherwise
provided in this subsection and subsection (4), records
regarding children and facts compiled about children and
their parents and relatives are confidential and disclosure
of this information shall be properly safeguarded by the
child care organization, the department, and any other
entity in possession of the information. Records that are
confidential under this section are available to both of the
following:
(a) A standing or select committee or appropriations
subcommittee of either house of the legislature having
jurisdiction over protective services matters for children,
according to section 7 of the child protection law, 1975 PA
238, MCL 722.627.
(b) The children’s ombudsman established in section 3 of
the children’s ombudsman act, 1994
PA 204, MCL 722.923.
In one out of three special evaluations reviewed, one social work contact included a
statement referencing CPS involvement. Also, the special evaluation included an
interview with the CPS worker detailing information that the CPS worker obtained
during one of his interviews for the investigation that he completed.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.

DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes.
FOM 722-06B
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home
cases:
• Case Plan Development/ Reassessment:
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Note: This FTM may be combined with the CPS Case
Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
• Placement preservation/disruption - At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement or
no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change. Planned and unplanned placement
changes include reunification, placement in a residential
setting, step-down from a residential or hospital setting,
return from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.
• Semi-Annual Transition Meeting - within 30 calendar days
after the youth’s 14th birthday and every six months
thereafter. For youth entering out-of-home placement at
age 14 or older, the semi-annual transition meeting must be
8

held within 30 calendar days of the removal date; see this
item for specific meeting requirements.
Documentation.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every
FTM.
In four out eight foster children’s records reviewed, a FTM was not completed timely
or the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting report, was not completed.
 For one foster child’s record, a FTM for case service plan development for the
USP ending on September 1, 2019 was not completed within 30 calendar

before the case plan due date.
 For one foster child’s record, a FTM for case service plan development for the
USP ending on October 20, 2019 was not completed within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.

DHHS Policy Caseworker Contact with Child in Out-of-Home Placement.
FOM 722-06H
First Two Months after Initial Placement or a Placement
Move
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face
contacts per month with the child for the first two months
following an initial placement or a placement move. The
first face-to-face contact with the child must take place
within five business days from the date the case is
assigned to the caseworker or within five business days of
the date of the placement move. At least one contact each
month must take place at the child’s placement location.
Each contact must include a private meeting between the
child and the caseworker.
Subsequent Months
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact
with the child each calendar month. At least one contact
each calendar month must take place at the child’s
9

placement location. Each con-tact must include a private
meeting between the child and the case-worker.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the caseworker did not have at
least two face-to-face contacts per month with the child for the first two months
following the placement move. The foster child was only seen once during the
second month after his change of placement.

July 5, 2018.

DHHS Policy Caseworker Contact With Parent(s)/Guardian(s).
FOM 722-06H
For each child with a permanency goal of reunification, the
child’s assigned caseworker must have face-to face contact
with the child’s parent/guardian as follows:
First Month after Initial Out-of-Home Placement
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face
contacts with each parent/guardian, at least one of which
must occur in the parent’s residence. One of the face-to-
face contacts must be used to discuss the following:
• Petition and court orders.
• Case service plan.
• Family Assessment of Needs and Strengths.
• Child Assessment of Needs and Strengths.
• Parent-Agency Treatment Plan & Service Agreement.
• Scheduling and expectations of parenting time.
Subsequent Months
The caseworker must have face-to-face contact with each
parent/guardian at least once each calendar month, with at
least one contact in each quarter occurring in the parent’s
place of residence.
10

In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, for the subsequent months,
the caseworker did not have face-to-face contact with each parent/guardian at least
once each calendar month, with at least one contact in each quarter occurring in the
parent’s place of residence. There was no face-to-face contact with the mother in the
parental home for report period June 4, 2019 to September 1, 2019. There were no
face-to-face contacts with the mother in September 2019 and October 2019.

DHHS Policy Timely Entry of Case Contacts.
FOM 722-06H
All case contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, including
attempted contacts and missed appointments. The case
contact narrative should consist of a brief summary of the
contact.
The required face-to-face contacts listed below must be
entered in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts.
• Any face-to-face contact with children, parents, or
caregivers made by any of the following:
Foster care caseworker/supervisor.
CPS caseworker/supervisor.
Adoption caseworker/supervisor.
Permanency resource monitors.
Education planners.
Michigan Youth Opportunities Initiative coordinators.
• Parent/child face-to-face contacts.
• Sibling face-to-face contacts.
All other case contacts must be entered prior to the report
period end date on the applicable case service plan.
In three out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, all case contacts were not
entered in MiSACWIS within five business days of the contact.
 For one foster child’s record, the January 7, 2020 face-to-face with the foster

2020. The September 11, 2019 contact with the birth mother was entered in

December 23, 2019 and February 18, 2020 sibling visits were entered in
MiSACWIS on June 12, 2020. The May 28, 2020 sibling visit was entered in
MiSACWIS on June 11, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, the February 12, 2020 and March 13, 2020
parenting time visits were entered in MiSACWIS on June 11, 2020. The face-

 For one foster child’s record, the May 20, 2020 sibling visit was entered in

DHHS Policy Maintaining Connections through Visitation and Contact:
FOM 722-06I Sibling Visitation and Ongoing Interaction.
Siblings in foster care, who are not placed together, must
have at least one visit per calendar month that is in addition
to parenting time. For the purposes of visitation only,
siblings include children related through birth, adoption, or
marriage and include siblings as defined by the American
Indian or Alaskan Native child's tribal code or custom. A
sibling relationship continues after termination of parental
rights or when a marriage ends by death or divorce.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, in which siblings were not
placed together, all of the monthly sibling visits were not completed. Sibling visits in
October 2019, November 2019, December 2019, January 2020, February 2020,
March 2020, April 2020 and May 2020 were not completed.

DHHS Policy Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
FOM 722-08E
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile
justice program/case closure, using the DHS 69 Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, the caseworker
must document:
 Reason for program/case closure.
 Reason the current program type continues to be
appropriate, if the child had multiple open programs
and one program has closed while the other remains
open.
 How and when information related to the care and
supervision of the child or program/case closure was
shared with relevant parties.
 Information given to parent(s), guardian, or youth
age 18 or older at program/case closure; see FOM
722-15, Case Closing.
The caseworker must document all case service delivery
from the report period end date of the previous case
service plan through the program or case closure date,
including:
 A summary of services that were provided during
care.
 A summary of services currently being provided.
 A list of services and needs still to be met and
provisions for follow up services, if any.
The caseworker must document whether:
 Medical information was given to the parents or next
placement and the date provided.
 Educational information was given to the parents or
next placement and the date provided.
 Closure was explained to all parties.
13

DHHS Policy Educational Services.
FOM 723
Every effort must be made to ensure that the educational
needs of all children in foster care are met. The supervising
agency must ensure that children in the care of MDHHS are
provided appropriate educational services to support and
encourage school success. The supervising agency is
responsible for monitoring the provision of educational
services to ensure identified needs are being addressed.
All educational information and related tasks, activities,
and contacts must be documented within the social work
contacts, case service plans, placement, and the education
section of MiSACWIS.
14

DHHS Policy Medical Passports.
FOM 801
For children first entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided to the foster care provider
within two weeks of the child's placement date. The actual
date the foster care provider receives the medical passport
must be documented in MiSACWIS.
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's
medical passport to another caseworker must sign and
date the medical passport verifying that s/he has sought
and obtained the necessary information under law and
MDHHS policy.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward.
--Quarterly.
--At reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
--At or prior to each placement.
--Quarterly.
15

In eight out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the medical passport was not
provided to the child’s foster care provider/parent or signed by the current foster care
worker per the timeframes specified in the policy.
 For one foster child’s record, the medical passport was not signed by the
current Oakland Family Services foster care worker.
 For one foster child’s record, the medical passport was not updated quarterly
and signed by the foster child’s first foster home placement. The foster child
was placed in this foster home on August 28, 2018, the agency received case
responsibility on November 18, 2019 and the foster child was removed from
the foster home on November 11, 2019. The foster parent signed the medical
passport on June 3, 2019. The foster child was placed in another foster home
on November 18, 2019 and the medical passport was not provided to the
foster parent prior to or at the time of the placement. The foster parent signed
the medical passport on January 27, 2020 and May 29, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, the medical passport was not updated quarterly.
The foster child was placed in the home on March 5, 2019 and the agency
received case responsibility on October 28, 2019. The relative caregiver
signed the medical passport on November 13, 2019 and May 26, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, the medical passport was not updated quarterly.
The foster child was placed in the foster home and the agency received case
responsibility on August 8, 2018. The foster parents signed the medical
passport on October 12, 2018, December 12, 2018 and February 27, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, the medical passport was not completed
quarterly. The agency received case responsibility on July 23, 2018 and the
foster child was placed with the current relative caregiver on July 23, 2018.
The relative signed the medical passport on February 7, 2019, October 17,
2019 and December 5, 2019.
 For one foster child’s record, the medical passport was not completed
quarterly and not signed by the current Oakland Family Services foster care
worker. The foster child was placed with the relative caregiver on August 28,
2019 and the agency received case responsibility on December 2, 2019. The
relative signed the medical passport on November 8, 2019.
 For one foster child’s record, the medical passport was not completed
quarterly. The agency received case responsibility on December 21, 2018.
The foster child was placed in one foster home from December 21, 2018 to
October 7, 2019. The medical passport was not signed quarterly by this foster
parent. The foster parent signed the medical passport on February 14, 2019.
The foster child was placed with the current relative caregiver on October 7,
2019. The relative caregiver was not provided the medical passport prior to or
